title: Mix master mix last and spin briefly
body: Prepare master mix on ice, mix gently 5 times, pulse spin, then aliquot into tubes

title: Primer final concentration
body: If primer final concentration is above 0.8 µM, non-specific bands may increase.

title: Volume mismatch
body: If water volume is negative, reduce primer or probe volumes, or increase reaction volume.

title: MW requirement for mass conversion
body: Mass units need molecular weight. Enter MW if converting mg/mL to molar target.

title: Use reverse pipetting for small volumes
body: Use reverse pipetting when transfer is small (<1 µL), then mix 10 times.

title: Use 2-step dilution above 1,000x
body: For large dilution factors, prefer 2-step dilution to reduce pipetting error.

title: Check insert purity before ligation
body: Unpurified insert often causes low transformation efficiency.

title: Approximation caution
body: This is an approximation; use fluorescent quantification when accuracy is required.

title: Avoid edge wells
body: Use edge-well fill controls because evaporation can increase concentration near edges.

title: Border cell handling
body: Count border cells consistently with your group to reduce bias.

title: Master-mix workflow
body: Mix water, buffer, dNTPs, primers, and polymerase first. Add template DNA last, then aliquot.

title: No overage
body: Do not skip overage; include extra volume for pipetting loss.

title: Recommended setup range
body: Use 10-20% overage and 10-50 uL reaction volume.

title: Primer dimer response
body: If primer dimer appears, increase annealing temperature or reduce primer concentration.

title: Mixing sequence
body: Calculate each stock volume from final target concentration, then add solvent to final volume.

title: Solvent-first overflow
body: Do not add all solvent first; adding stocks later can exceed final volume.

title: Pipetting lower bound
body: Set stock concentrations so each pipetted volume is at least 1 uL.

title: Precipitation check
body: If precipitation appears, verify buffer compatibility and mix gently at room temperature.

title: Step transfer protocol
body: Preload diluent, transfer fixed volume from high concentration to next tube, and mix thoroughly each step.

title: Tip carryover
body: Change pipette tips between steps to avoid high-concentration carryover.

title: Dilution factor range
body: Recommended per-step dilution factor is 1:2 to 1:10.

title: Nonlinear curve
body: If standard curve is nonlinear, vortex thoroughly before every transfer.

title: Mass to copies workflow
body: Measure ng/uL, convert mass to moles using sequence length, then multiply by Avogadro number.

title: ss/ds constant confusion
body: Do not mix single-stranded and double-stranded molecular weight constants.

title: Standard-curve window
body: Typical standard curve range is 10^1 to 10^9 copies per reaction.

title: Low copy yield
body: If copies are low, check extraction efficiency and A260/280 purity.

title: Ligation setup flow
body: Calculate insert:vector molar ratio, then mix DNA, ligase buffer, and T4 ligase for incubation.

title: Mass ratio misuse
body: Use molar ratio (fmol), not mass ratio (ng), for insert:vector planning.

title: Insert:vector ratio
body: A practical starting range is 3:1 to 5:1 insert:vector molar ratio.

title: No colony recovery
body: If no colonies appear, verify ligase buffer ATP quality or increase insert ratio.

title: Blanking method
body: Blank with the exact elution buffer, then read absorbance at 260 nm.

title: Wrong blank solution
body: Do not blank with water if the sample is dissolved in another buffer.

title: Read quality range
body: A260 of 0.1-1.0 is practical; A260/A280 around 1.8 for DNA and 2.0 for RNA.

title: Low A260/280
body: If A260/280 is below 1.6, protein contamination is likely; repurify the sample.

title: Seeding sequence
body: Count cells, calculate total cells/volume for well format, dilute, and plate evenly.

title: No pre-plating resuspension
body: Resuspend right before dispensing; otherwise well-to-well density drifts.

title: Density range
body: Typical starting range is 10^4 to 10^5 cells/cm2 depending on cell type.

title: Center clumping
body: If cells accumulate in center, move plate gently in cross motion (up-down, left-right).

title: Trypan counting workflow
body: Mix cells with Trypan blue at 1:1, load chamber, and count live/dead cells under microscope.

title: Chamber overfill
body: Overfilling changes fixed chamber volume assumptions and distorts counts.

title: Countable range
body: Aim for 20-50 cells per large square for stable counting.

title: Too many cells
body: If cells are too dense to count, further dilute original sample and recount.

title: Rotor-normalized conversion
body: Measure actual rotor radius and convert RPM to RCF to standardize between instruments.

title: Paper RPM copy
body: Do not copy RPM from literature without adjusting for rotor radius differences.

title: Common force ranges
body: Cell pelleting often uses 300-500 x g; DNA precipitation commonly uses >12,000 x g.

title: No pellet
body: If pellet does not form, verify that target RCF was not mistakenly treated as RPM.

title: Dye-inclusive loading
body: Mix DNA with loading dye to 1X final concentration (for 6X dye, 1 uL dye per 5 uL sample+water), then load total volume.

title: Overloading risk
body: Avoid excess DNA mass or exceeding well capacity; both can smear bands or spill into adjacent wells.

title: Loading window
body: A practical target is 50-100 ng per expected band and below 70-80% of well maximum volume.

title: Wavy or faint bands
body: Check agarose percentage for target size and confirm running buffer (TAE/TBE) is fresh enough.
